posts.name: csos
posts.cooked:
Hello everyone!

Our team has recently started brainstorming ideas for autonomous strategies, and we’re curious to hear what others in the community think. We’d love to learn about the most effective or creative autonomous routines teams are working on this season.

If you have a favorite autonomous strategy or scenario your team is developing, we’d be grateful if you could share it here. Let’s inspire each other and make this season’s autonomous plays the best yet!

posts.name: Caleb Ryon
posts.cooked: We plan to do 3 L4 and grab one algae.

posts.name: Ethan Grieshop
posts.cooked: I think versatility will be huge this year. A lot of teams will likely have a limited number of paths, confining them to certain areas that are hard to maneuver around for alliance members. Being able to score 3 or 4 coral in auton while enabling your alliance members to do the same will be the best way to stand out.

posts.name: Nolan Fair
posts.cooked: This is our teams plan. when we won state we were the 3rd pic for our alliance team because of our versatile autos. We are trying to incorporate vision into the auto instead of setpoints which should be a fun challenge.

posts.name: John Bottenberg
posts.cooked: Versatility is good, but the routines also need to be consistent. If you’re going for repeated L4 coral scores, then before working on making your auto versatile, it might be worth it to make sure the consistency of scoring is at or near 100%. There were many impressive-looking centerline autos last year that would miss shots or miss intakings of notes.

Everyone’s talking about L4 and all which is a good priority to have. One thing everyone should worry about is alliance robot collisions. Having 2 robots fully extended to L4 and colliding would be very bad.

posts.name: Andy Nguyen
posts.cooked: To be compatible with the most amount of teams, teams should at a minimum have a auto for left/right/back of the reef (assuming you are scoring coral)

posts.name: CoreyBrown
posts.cooked: I think moving off the line, then scoring whichever coral is your closest to 100% accuracy is going to be a good start.

posts.name: Liam
posts.cooked: because its a +2 for L3 and L4 I wouldnt be surprised if teams attempt to take advantage of it and do more L3 than L4 if it is resonably faster for auto

posts.name: Pat Mattin
posts.cooked: Not sure when L3 would be faster, you have to remove an algae to score there. That reduces consistency too much in my mind.
